Headline: Optometrist/ Training and development/ Sales Enabler/ Myopia Management/ Ophthalmic device/ Contact Lenses/ Intra Ocular Lenses/ Dry Eyes / Glucoma/
Comment: Dilip Kumar The reduced life expectancy of doctors compared to their patients in India stems from the belief that longer training periods and rigorous filtering alone can ensure the development of quality healthcare providers to address the country‚Äôs massive healthcare crisis. However, this approach often worsens the situation by overburdening the system and negatively impacting doctors' quality of life, contributing to their shorter lifespans. Constantly requiring doctors to clear multiple competency exams does little to improve care and, in the worst-case scenario, adds strain to an already overstretched healthcare system. To address this, India must reform its medical education by promoting collaborative and shared care delivery across various levels, and by recognizing that extending doctors' life expectancy by even a decade would have a more meaningful impact than simply increasing the number of medical seats, only to force new doctors into an already broken system.

A broken system that doesn‚Äôt protect its caretakers cannot sustain itself.

One part is external‚Äîa shortage of doctors. Too few shoulders to carry the weight of too many patients. This creates long hours, relentless demand, and exhaustion. The system simply doesn‚Äôt have enough hands.

Headline: Anesthesiologist, Kaiser South Sacramento
Comment:
Dilip Kumar unhealthy lifestyle including lack of physical activity, poor diet and stress is widely prevalent in India. And these are the top 3 reasons for high mortality. Doctors have all the information and the money to buy technology or AI. But the issue is much deeper and cultural. For example, 30 minute simple excercise should be integral part of your day. But not many parents teach the importance of exercise, which carries on with them. Also, there are no good facilities for excercise or even walking/running  spaces in the cities, forget about running on the streets, you can be run over by a car or chased by dogs. 

So huge part of India‚Äôs health problems are poor infrastructure and cultural problems, not technology problems. 

(Well I am frustrated because whenever I come here I cannot find a good place to run and none of my doctors friends wants to runüòä)

Comment:
Doctors have a brutal regime...

Getting in, with the Neet exam, is where the mental pressure begins - in 8th or 9th graders. Lakhs of kids competing for a few thousand seats, at an age when they have no emotional maturity,  just really big dreams...

And it gets progressively more difficult.  Sleep, exercise are illusions, there are times when u live on parle G and tea... or worse, cigarettes...

Life gets no easier, ever. 

Its probably the most brutal career to train for, with very little systemic support and extremely delayed rewards...

Headline: Co-Founder @iThrive I Enabling & witnessing the growth of the wonder named @iThrive I A Divine Soul I
Comment:
Equating doctors and/or hospitals with Health or healthcare is a gross misunderstanding of that industry . At best they are a sickness care provider. Also most doctors are emergency service specialist. The entire medical curriculum is designed to treat illness or handle emergency/Trauma/Surgeries. We shouldn't be looking up to them as as HEALTH role models. They cant be because they are not taught to make people healthy but treat ailments and address emergencies. We need a different "Health" only ecosystem which will take away burden from the existing "Sick care" ecosystem so that the doctors/hospitals can focus what they are trained to do , Address emergencies, do life saving surgeries, Attend to Trauma cases etc. 

We don't need to correct the existing model, its is good for what it is created for. We need to create alternate model of healthcare where doctors are no longer role models but as human as rest of us.

Headline: Business Transformation Leader | CMD, Cogilys Fincorp Pvt Ltd & Founder, Med24x7 | Strategic Consultant | Sales & Marketing Architect | HealthTech & FinServ Innovator | Bridging AI and ROI through Vision & Execution
Comment:
Dilip Kumar, you‚Äôre right. India‚Äôs doctors aren‚Äôt just dying early‚Äîthey‚Äôre being systemically failed. But history shows us that even the most entrenched crises can be reversed with political will and collective action. Here‚Äôs how we can turn this around:

Global playbook India must adopt now:
Work-Hour Reform
 US caps at 80 hrs/week, EU at 48 hrs/week. India? 100+ hours with no regulation.
  Fix: Amend the Factories Act to include healthcare.
Mental Health Support
 US/UK offer confidential, anonymous therapy. 
India? Stigma + no access.
  Fix: 1 counsellor per 100 beds via state schemes.
Violence Protection
 Australia has panic buttons, & Canada runs ‚ÄúCode White.‚Äù
 India? Silence.
  Fix: Enforce ‚ÄúCode Silver‚Äù + fast-track courts.
Admin Relief
 Scandinavia uses AI; Germany mandates scribes.
 India? 30% of doctors' time is lost to paperwork.
 Fix: Subsidise AI scribes under Ayushman Bharat.
Training Reform
 The US & the Netherlands teach emotional resilience. India? Rote learning.
  Fix: Upgrade AETCOM with mandatory wellness modules.
Wellness Incentives
 The US pays stipends, & France adds 20% pay for stress roles.
 India? No incentive.
  Fix: Link pay to burnout zones + wellness metrics.
This isn‚Äôt charity; it‚Äôs economic survival.

Headline: Robotic and advanced Laparoscopic surgeon
Comment:
Thanks for your concern.  I can site a few remedies for this .
1. Stop having impractical expectations from the treatment . Social media false claims and faux advertisements  by private hospitals add fuel to this expectations. 
2. Do not try to treat your doctor as God,  he has no magic power . He is like other professionals who helps you when you are in trouble.
3. Trust your doctor fully ,but if you have slightest of doubt move on. A doctor has a peaceful mind  when he finds that the patient trusts him fully.
4. Do not judge a doctor by the sheer number of Google reviews or presence of patients in the waiting area. You can buy those.
There is a difference between a good doctor and a famous doctor that you will have to judge.
5. Take active part in the decision making by your doctor.
6.All these will help the doctor to go for defensive medicine at your own cost.

For the doctors  - To some of us it appears that there is no tomorrow. We forget that the doctors are responsible for their families and more importantly their own health.
Peer pressure to own an expensive flat or a car or face book publications for exotic holiday pics doesn't yield patients. It is the time given to them  with a  little honesty that matter most.

I would go to a skilled doctor using AI, than the hospitals that are completely running on AI.
Because it's the empathy and the human touch that makes traversing critical health conditions better. Not just precise tech solutions.

And I have personally seen my doctor friends leave everything and tirelessly work for days without break. And wonder how can a system be built to ensure they focus on their health too‚ÄîA problem statement that actually needs tech or system intervention, in my opinion.

Comment:
AI won't make doctors obsolete anytime soon; if anything, doctors will now have one more task of navigating around AI learned patients. 
First the softwares that added clicks but did little to improve patient care, and now AI, that will very confidently misguide the patients with a disclaimer shrugging off the responsibility. 
This piece is a reality check for those building patient facing LLM powered tools: https://amirkiani.xyz/posts/yari-care-nav/

Headline: Biomedical Scientist (Neurogenetics) | Entrepreneur | Longevity | STEM Mentor |
Comment:
Dilip Kumar Absolutely, the medical fraternity puts so much of time and effort into working towards people‚Äôs better health. 
An important point, It boils down to supply and demand Biomedicine unlike the Tech space needs a long time in training. No other domain grew in so much of understanding over the last few decades as Biomedical Sciences.  So there is a huge shortage in the number of people who get trained. An other extremely ignored domain in biomedical Scientists and researchers who contributed to the development. They equally toil for 12-15hrs a day with very poor outcomes, as they are mostly invisible to society.  
This is nothing to do with lacking empathy for clinicians. The point to raise the thought of the entire community who contribute to betterment of health!

Headline: Startups | Tech | Infra | Finance
Comment:
Mental Health of doctors is also generally very poor, often overburdened but also greatly isolated. Unlike other professions say Bankers who work with each other, Doctors particularly running their own clinics barely interact with their own colleagues/classmates/friends leading to further isolation.

We had a family doctor uncle (my parents' friend) from Sir Sundar Lal - Lucknow, undoubtedly a high achieving genius with extreme detail to attention, who saw our entire family for some 35 odd years; who died couple years ago at age 63. Towards last decade of his life, he has become increasingly lonely, isolated, separated from his wife, chain smoker, and drowned himself in work and books - yet lonely amid the crowd of nurses, compounders and patients. 

Signs of this loneliness and isolation and lack of friends/community around doctors can be seen in mid 40s, as soon as they get more senior and move out from Hospital job system to their own clinic system. 

Sometimes, I deduce, friends and community is the highest life extending agent, ahead of nutrition, exercise and everything else.
